sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• before initiating treatment; weigh the potential benefits and risks of therapy and of other treatment options
  • to reduce the risk of serious adverse effects; use the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible duration
  • after initial treatment response is observed; adjust the dosage to the individual patient's needs
  • Ankylosing spondylitis: 275 to 550 mg ORALLY twice a day; MAX 1650 mg/day for up to 6 months
  • Ankylosing spondylitis: controlled-release, 750 to 1000 mg ORALLY once daily; may increase to 1500 mg ORALLY once daily for a limited time; use lowest effective dose
  • Bursitis: initial, 550 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 550 mg ORALLY every 12 hours as needed or 275 mg ORALLY every 6 to 8 hours as needed; MAX initial 1375 mg/day, then 1100 mg/day
  • Bursitis: controlled release, 1000 mg ORALLY once a day; may increase to 1500 mg ORALLY once daily for a limited period, thereafter the dose should not exceed 1000 mg/day
  • Fever: over-the-counter, initial, 220 to 440 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 220 mg ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours as needed; do not take longer than 10 days unless directed by physician; MAX dose, 440 mg in any 8 to 12 hour period, 660 mg per 24 hours
  • Gout, acute: initial, 825 mg; maintenance, 275 mg ORALLY every 8 hours
  • Gout, acute: controlled release, initial, 1000 to 1500 mg ORALLY on the first day; maintenance, 1000 mg ORALLY once a day until the attack subsides
  • Headache: over-the-counter, initial, 220 to 440 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 220 mg ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours as needed; do not take longer than 10 days unless directed by physician; MAX dose, 440 mg in any 8 to 12 hour period, 660 mg per 24 hours
  • Osteoarthritis: 275 to 550 mg ORALLY twice a day; MAX 1650 mg/day for up to 6 months
  • Osteoarthritis: controlled-release, 750 to 1000 mg ORALLY once daily; may increase to 1500 mg ORALLY once daily for a limited time; use lowest effective dose
  • Pain: initial, 550 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 550 mg ORALLY every 12 hours as needed or 275 mg ORALLY every 6 to 8 hours as needed; MAX initial 1375 mg/day, then 1100 mg/day
  • Pain: controlled release, initial, 1000 mg ORALLY once a day; may increase to 1500 mg ORALLY once daily for a limited period, thereafter the dose should not exceed 1000 mg/day
  • Pain: over-the-counter, initial, 220 to 440 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 220 mg ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours as needed; do not take longer than 10 days unless directed by physician; MAX dose, 440 mg in any 8 to 12 hour period, 660 mg per 24 hours
  • Primary dysmenorrhea: initial, 550 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 550 mg ORALLY every 12 hours as needed or 275 mg ORALLY every 6 to 8 hours as needed; MAX initial 1375 mg/day, then 1100 mg/day
  • Primary dysmenorrhea: controlled release, initial, 1000 mg ORALLY once a day; may increase to 1500 mg ORALLY once daily for a limited period, thereafter the dose should not exceed 1000 mg/day
  • Primary dysmenorrhea: over-the-counter dosing (ages 12 years and older), initial, 220 to 440 mg ORALLY; maintenance 220 mg ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours as needed; do not take longer than 10 days unless directed by physician; MAX dose, 440 mg in any 8 to 12 hour period, 660 mg per 24 hours
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: 275 to 550 mg ORALLY twice a day; MAX 1650 mg/day for up to 6 months
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: controlled-release, 750 to 1000 mg ORALLY once daily; may increase to 1500 mg ORALLY once daily for a limited time; use lowest effective dose
  • Tendinitis, acute: initial, 550 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 550 mg ORALLY every 12 hours as needed or 275 mg ORALLY every 6 to 8 hours as needed; MAX initial 1375 mg/day, then 1100 mg/day
  • Tendinitis, acute: controlled release, 1000 mg ORALLY once a day; may increase to 1500 mg ORALLY once daily for a limited period, thereafter the dose should not exceed 1000 mg/day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy of controlled-release naproxen sodium not established in pediatric patients
  • safety and efficacy of naproxen sodium not established in pediatric patients under 2 years of age
  • before initiating treatment; weigh the potential benefits and risks of therapy and of other treatment options
  • to reduce the risk of serious adverse effects; use the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible duration
  • after initial treatment response is observed; adjust the dosage to the individual patient's needs
  • Fever: over-the-counter, ages 12 years and older, initial, 220 to 440 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 220 mg ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours as needed; do not take longer than 10 days unless directed by physician; MAX dose, 440 mg in any 8 to 12 hour period, 660 mg per 24 hours
  • Headache: over-the-counter, 12 years and older, initial, 220 to 440 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 220 mg ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours as needed; do not take longer than 10 days unless directed by physician; MAX dose, 440 mg in any 8 to 12 hour period, 660 mg per 24 hours
  • Pain: over-the-counter dosing, 12 years and older, initial, 220 to 440 mg ORALLY; maintenance, 220 mg ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours as needed; do not take longer than 10 days unless directed by physician; MAX dose, 440 mg in any 8 to 12 hour period, 660 mg per 24 hours
  • Primary dysmenorrhea: over-the-counter dosing (ages 12 years and older), initial, 220 to 440 mg ORALLY; maintenance 220 mg ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours as needed; do not take longer than 10 days unless directed by physician; MAX dose, 440 mg in any 8 to 12 hour period, 660 mg per 24 hours
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: children 2 years and older, 10 mg/kg/day ORALLY given in 2 divided doses (5 mg/kg given twice a day)

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• geriatric: initiate treatment at the lowest end of the dosing range and when higher doses are indicated, a dose adjustment may be necessary
  • geriatric: do not take more than 220 mg every 12 hours, unless directed by doctor
  • renal impairment, mild: initiate treatment at the lowest end of the dosing range and when higher doses are indicated, a dose adjustment may be necessary
  • renal impairment, moderate to severe (CrCl less than 30 mL/min), and advanced renal disease: use is not recommended
  • hepatic impairment: initiate treatment at the lowest end of the dosing range and when higher doses are indicated, a dose adjustment may be necessary.

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Tablet, Extended Release; Tablet)
NSAIDs may cause an increased risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events, myocardial infarction, and stroke, which can be fatal. This risk may be increased in patients with cardiovascular disease or risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Naproxen sodium is contraindicated for the treatment of perioperative pain in the setting of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. NSAIDs can also cause an increased risk of serious gastrointestinal adverse events especially in the elderly, including bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines, which can be fatal.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reaction following aspirin or other NSAID administration; severe, even fatal anaphylactic-like reactions have been reported
  • coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery, treatment of perioperative pain
  • hypersensitivity to naproxen or naproxen sodium

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cardiovascular thrombotic events; myocardial infarction, stroke, potentially fatal, have been reported; risk may increase with duration of use
  • cardiovascular disease, known or risk factors for; increased risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events, myocardial infarction, and stroke
  • elderly; increased risk of renal toxicity or injury, and serious gastrointestinal adverse events (bleeding, ulceration, perforation of stomach or intestines) that can occur at any time and without warning
  • gastrointestinal adverse events; ulceration, bleeding, or perforation of stomach or intestines, potentially fatal may occur without warning; increased risk with concurrent use of corticosteroids, anticoagulants, or aspirin, smoking, alcohol use, or poor general health status
  • alcoholic liver disease, chronic, or other disease with decreased plasma proteins; dose adjustments recommended
  • anaphylactoid reactions may occur
  • anemia may occur
  • aspirin sensitive asthma; use not recommended
  • aspirin triad (bronchospasm in asthmatic patients with rhinitis, with or without nasal polyps following aspirin or NSAID administration); use not recommended
  • asthma, preexisting; risk of severe and potentially fatal bronchospasm
  • coagulation disorders; may inhibit platelet aggregation and prolong bleeding time; monitoring recommended
  • extended duration of therapy; increased risk of renal papillary necrosis, renal injury, or potentially fatal gastrointestinal bleeding, ulceration, or perforation that may occur without warning
  • fluid retention or heart failure; edema, fluid retention, and peripheral edema have been reported
  • gastrointestinal bleeding or history of ulcers, existing; increased risk of ulceration, bleeding, or perforation of stomach or intestines, potentially fatal
  • hepatic enzymes (ALT, AST), elevated, has been reported; discontinuation required if abnormal liver test occurs
  • hepatic reactions, including jaundice and fatal fulminant hepatitis, liver necrosis, and hepatic failure, have been reported; discontinuation required for symptoms of or evidence of hepatic reaction
  • inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease), history of; increased risk of exacerbation
  • hypertension; new onset or worsening of hypertension may occur; monitoring recommended
  • pregnancy, late; risk of premature closure of ductus; avoid use
  • renal disease, advance; use not recommended
  • renal papillary necrosis and other renal injury may occur; increased risk with concurrent use of ACE inhibitors and diuretics, heart failure, liver dysfunction, impaired renal function, hypovolemia, or salt-depletion; discontinuation may be warranted
  • salt-depleted; increased risk of renal toxicity or injury
  • skin reactions; potentially fatal adverse events including exfoliative dermatitis, Stevens Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis may occur; discontinue at first signs of skin rash or hypersensitivity
  • sodium restricted diet, severe; drug contains sodium
  • thiazide or loop diuretics; risk of impaired response; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (3% to 9%), Constipation (3% to 9%), Heartburn (3% to 9%), Indigestion (14%), Nausea (3% to 9%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (3% to 15%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Edema (3% to 9%), Myocardial infarction (less than 1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Esophagitis (less than 1%), Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (less than 1%), Gastrointestinal perforation, Gastrointestinal ulcer
  • Hepatic:Pancreatitis (less than 1%)
  • Renal:Renal failure (less than 1%)

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: The anti-inflammatory effect of naproxen may involve its ability to inhibit prostaglandin synthesis. The sodium salt formulation allows for more rapid absorption.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Immediate release: 1 to 2 hours; controlled release, 5 hours
  • Tmax, Controlled-release: 5 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: 95%
  • Effect of food, Immediate-release, Single dose: 2-hour delay in Tmax; 21% reduction in Cmax

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Vd: 0.16 L/kg
  • Protein binding: Greater than 99% to albumin

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: Less than 3%
  • Renal: 95% primarily as conjugated unchanged drug or metabolites
  • Dialyzable: No (hemodialysis)
  • Total body clearance: 0.13 mL/min/kg

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Oral
  • (controlled-release tablets) do not crush, break or chew
  • take with a full glass of water; take with food or milk if stomach upset occurs

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• rheumatoid arthritis/osteoarthritis: improved range of motion, decreased early morning stiffness and painful/swollen joints, C-reactive protein levels, erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • acute gout/bursitis/dysmenorrhea/pain/tendonitis: relief of pain
  • CBC, chemistry profile, blood pressure, fecal occult blood test, liver function; after initiation of NSAID therapy and every 6-12 months thereafter, more frequently in patients at risk for hepatic, renal, cardiac, or gastrointestinal toxicity (eg, age greater than 60 years, high-dose NSAID therapy, concurrent corticosteroids or anticoagulants, history of cardiac, renal, or hepatic disease)
  • hemoglobin, hematocrit; in long-term therapy patients with signs/symptoms of anemia
  • signs and symptoms of hepatic toxicity
  • signs and symptoms of skin reaction

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
NAPROXEN
USES: Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used as a pain medication and in various inflammatory conditions. PHARMACOLOGY: Naproxen is a nonselective inhibitor of cyclooxygenases (COX-1 and COX-2), leading to decreased synthesis of prostanoids. Naproxen, like other NSAIDs, has anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic properties. TOXICOLOGY: Prostaglandin inhibition is responsible for the gastrointestinal irritant effects and nephrotoxicity. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Poisoning with NSAIDs is not uncommon but rarely severe. Naproxen overdose is uncommon in the United States since other NSAIDs are used more often. MILD TO MODERATE POISONING: Gastrointestinal effects (eg, dyspepsia, ulceration, bleeding) are most commonly encountered. Renal dysfunction, most often in elderly patients, may occur. Mild CNS effects include altered cognition, drowsiness, headache, and mood changes, especially in the elderly population. SEVERE POISONING: Severe poisoning is rare but can include CNS depression, hallucinations, seizures, renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, and metabolic acidosis. ADVERSE EFFECTS: CNS effects include drowsiness, headache, fatigue, and cognition disturbances, especially in the elderly. Gastrointestinal effects (eg, dyspepsia, ulceration, bleeding) are as common as with other NSAIDs. Renal dysfunction, especially in the elderly population, may be seen. Instances of agranulocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and pancreatitis have been reported. Hepatotoxicity is rare.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
NAPROXEN
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Primarily supportive care; activated charcoal may not be necessary given the fast gastrointestinal absorption of the drug and anticipated mild toxicity. Give benzodiazepines titrated to effect for anxiety and seizures. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: If significant CNS depression occurs, consider orotracheal intubation for airway protection before giving charcoal. Give benzodiazepines for anxiety, agitation, delirium, and seizures. Be aware of the risk of renal failure and gastrointestinal bleeding. Avoid nephrotoxic drugs.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Not recommended because of potential for somnolence and seizures. HOSPITAL: Consider activated charcoal if patients present early after a substantial ingestion. However, be aware of fast drug absorption and the potential for significant CNS toxicity early in the clinical course.
  • Airway management: Early orotracheal intubation in patients with signs of severe intoxication with CNS depression, seizures, or agitation.
  • Antidote: None
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs and mental status. Naproxen plasma levels are not clinically useful or readily available. No specific lab work is needed in most patients. Obtain routine chemistry, blood gases, and CBC in case of severe toxicity.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: There is no role for repeat-dose activated charcoal. Hemodialysis is not useful given the high protein binding.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Asymptomatic children and adults with inadvertent ingestions can be managed at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Symptomatic patients and those with deliberate overdose should be sent to a health care facility for evaluation. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients with serious CNS depression, agitation or seizures, renal failure, significant metabolic acidosis, and severe gastrointestinal toxicity (ie, bleeding) require admission. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a poison center or medical toxicologist for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is not clear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
NAPROXEN
TOXICITY: Severe toxicity developed in an adolescent who ingested 13.75 g and in an adult who ingested 90 g of naproxen. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULTS: 250 to 500 mg orally twice daily. PEDIATRIC: 5 mg/kg orally twice daily.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Advise pregnant patients to avoid use during late pregnancy as this may result in premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.
  • Drug may cause headache, back pain, heartburn, dizziness, drowsiness, lightheadedness, or insomnia.
  • Tell patient to report unexplained weight gain or edema.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of serious skin adverse events including skin rash, itching, or blisters.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of serious cardiovascular events, especially those with known, or risk factors for, cardiovascular disease.
  • Tell patients to report signs/symptoms of gastrointestinal ulceration or bleeding, or hepatotoxicity (eg, nausea, fatigue, jaundice).
  • Advise patient to avoid concomitant aspirin use.
